description: From Haitian Creole manbo (“voodoo priestess”) (ultimately from Yoruba mambo (“to talk”)), in later senses via Cuban Spanish mambo (“dance”).

nouns.description: mambo (countable and uncountable, plural mambos or mamboes)

examples: The mambo next presented a container of water to the cardinal points, then poured libations to the centerpost of the peristyle, the axis along which the spirits were to enter.

entries.meaning: A Latin-American musical genre, adapted from rumba, originating from Cuba in the 1940s, or a dance or rhythm of this genre. [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: mambo (third-person singular simple present mambos, present participle mamboing, simple past and past participle mamboed)
